items.title: Stacked (filled) lines
items.body:
Here's a quick and dirty implementation of stacked lines, by subclassing Line and hacking the data:
```python
class Filled(Line):
    def to_svg(self, width, height, x_scale, y_scale, series, palette):
        group = super().to_svg(
            width=width, height=height, x_scale=x_scale, y_scale=y_scale,
            series=series, palette=palette)

        path = group[0]
        path_d = path.get('d').split(' ')

        # Go down to Y 0.
        path_d.extend(['V', six.text_type(y_scale.project(0, height, 0))])
        # Go back to t0 X.
        path_d.extend(['H', path_d[1]])
        # Close path.
        path_d.extend(['Z'])

        # Set fill to stroke and stroke to none. And update 'd'.
        path.set('fill', path.get('stroke'))
        path.set('stroke', 'none')
        path.set('d', ' '.join(path_d))

        return group
```
Data:

1. Make sure you accumulate y-values of all lines, so the "top" lines have the Y-values of all the lines below them.

2. Then, instead of add_line, add the Filled line from above. Make sure you add in reverse order. (The highest Y-value should be drawn first.)
```python
            if stacked:
                chart.add_series(
                    Series(data=lines[idx], name=labels[idx]),
                    Filled(stroke_color=colors[idx]))
            else:
                chart.add_line(
                    data=lines[idx], name=labels[idx],
                    stroke_color=color[idx])

items.title: Exception generating bar chart with a text column
items.body:
Hi,
I wanted to style an agate bar chart generated in the following manner :

```python
import agate
import leather

my_table = agate.Table.from_csv('mycsvdata.csv')
grp_by_status = mytable.group_by('status')
aggr_by_status = gb.aggregate([('nb', agate.Count())])
# This first chart is working fine
aggr_by_status.bar_chart('What is your status ?', 'nb', path='agate.svg')

chart = leather.Chart('What is your status ?')
chart.add_x_axis(name='status')
chart.add_y_axis(name='nb')
chart.add_bars(aggr_by_status, x='status', y='nb')
# An exception is triggered
chart.to_svg(path='leather.svg')
```
When I try to use leather, I get an exception `ValueError: 0 is not in list`.

The following code seems to reproduce the problem with simple data :

```python
import leather

mydata = [('happy', 20), ('unhappy', 10)]

mychart = leather.Chart('Reproduce problem')
mychart.add_x_axis(name='status')
mychart.add_y_axis(name='nb')
mychart.add_bars(mydata)

mychart.to_svg(path='test.svg')
```
This is happening with Python 3.5.2 and leather 0.3.2

Thanks for your libraries.

items.title: Missing dependency: lxml
items.body: Not sure what the required version is, but `pip install lxml` worked fine.

items.title: Lattice bar/column charts don't work if groups have different labels
items.body:
From wireservice/agate#643

```
import agate

# Group by county
counties = leso.group_by('county')

# Filter to counties with more than $200,000 in equipment
top_counties = counties.having([
    ('total_cost_sum', agate.Sum('total_cost'))
], lambda t: t['total_cost_sum'] > 200000)

# Group a second time—see the section on "Multidimensional aggregation"
counties_and_items = top_counties.group_by('federal_supply_category_name')

# Aggregate sums by county and item
counts = counties_and_items.aggregate([
    ('quantity_sum', agate.Sum('quantity'))
])

# Sort by item, regroup by county, and then plot a line chart for each county
counts.order_by('quantity_sum', reverse=True).group_by('federal_supply_category_name').bar_chart(label='federal_supply_category_name', value='quantity_sum')
```

```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-105-ed28ead4c510> in <module>()
     18 
     19 # Sort by item, regroup by county, and then plot a line chart for each county
---> 20 counts.order_by('quantity_sum', reverse=True).group_by('federal_supply_category_name').bar_chart(label='federal_supply_category_name', value='quantity_sum')

/Users/cgroskopf/src/agate/agate/tableset/bar_chart.py in bar_chart(self, label, value, path, width, height)
     31         label_name = label
     32 
---> 33     if type(value) is int:
     34         value_name = self.column_names[value]
     35     else:

/Users/cgroskopf/.virtualenvs/agate/lib/python3.5/site-packages/leather/lattice.py in to_svg(self, path, width, height)
    150 
    151         if not self._scales[Y]:
--> 152             self._scales[Y]= Scale.infer(layers, Y, self._types[Y])
    153 
    154         if not self._axes[X]:

/Users/cgroskopf/.virtualenvs/agate/lib/python3.5/site-packages/leather/scales/base.py in infer(cls, layers, dimension, data_type)
     87 
     88                 if series.values(dimension) != scale_values:
---> 89                     raise ValueError('All series must have the same values for scale display.')
     90 
     91             scale = Ordinal(scale_values)

ValueError: All series must have the same values for scale display.
```

items.title: Bars do not display top-down
items.body: Not sure when this happened but reversing data in `Bars.to_svg` no longer affects the order of rendered bars.

items.title: How do you get it to actually display?
items.body:
I must admit that I'm confused, but I suspect that at least some other potential users would be similarly confused. So I think not addressing this more clearly may be a lapse in the documentation worthy of putting into an issue. 

When running the first example at http://leather.readthedocs.io/en/latest/examples.html, everything seems to run properly, but nothing is displayed. And I can't find anything in the docs about how to make it display.

I'm on OS X 10.11.5, running Anaconda's Python 2.7.

Could you please clarify how to make it display? Or maybe, if the problem is just that Anaconda's Python won't work, you could give some clue about what Python distributions are OK?

items.title: Automatically coerce key values to strings
items.body:
Currently using non-string key values in the data set is impossible. When changing the [columns example](http://leather.readthedocs.io/en/latest/examples.html#columns) to only include non-string values the following exception is thrown:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/cryzed/Documents/Code/Sandbox/columns.py", line 12, in <module>
    chart.to_svg('examples/charts/columns.svg')
  File "/home/cryzed/.conda/envs/Sandbox3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/leather/chart.py", line 326, in to_svg
    group = self.to_svg_group(width, height)
  File "/home/cryzed/.conda/envs/Sandbox3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/leather/chart.py", line 291, in to_svg_group
    series_group.append(series.to_svg(canvas_width, canvas_height, x_scale, y_scale))
  File "/home/cryzed/.conda/envs/Sandbox3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/leather/series.py", line 126, in to_svg
    return self._shape.to_svg(width, height, x_scale, y_scale, self)
  File "/home/cryzed/.conda/envs/Sandbox3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/leather/shapes/columns.py", line 32, in to_svg
    x1, x2 = x_scale.project_interval(x, 0, width)
  File "/home/cryzed/.conda/envs/Sandbox3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/leather/scales/linear.py", line 32, in project_interval
    raise NotImplementedError
NotImplementedError
```

The object's string representation should be used for the text display in the chart. Comparison between used key objects (for sorting etc.) can obviously still be done before coercing them to strings.

items.title: ZeroDivisionError for Columns chart with exclusively 0-values
items.body:
When changing the [columns example](http://leather.readthedocs.io/en/latest/examples.html#columns) to only have values of 0 in the data set, leather throws the following exception:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/cryzed/Documents/Code/Sandbox/columns.py", line 12, in <module>
    chart.to_svg('examples/charts/columns.svg')
  File "/home/cryzed/.conda/envs/Sandbox3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/leather/chart.py", line 326, in to_svg
    group = self.to_svg_group(width, height)
  File "/home/cryzed/.conda/envs/Sandbox3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/leather/chart.py", line 281, in to_svg_group
    axes_group.append(y_axis.to_svg(canvas_width, canvas_height, y_scale, 'left'))
  File "/home/cryzed/.conda/envs/Sandbox3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/leather/axis.py", line 111, in to_svg
    projected_value = scale.project(value, range_min, range_max)
  File "/home/cryzed/.conda/envs/Sandbox3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/leather/scales/linear.py", line 23, in project
    pos = float(value - self.min) / (self.max - self.min)
ZeroDivisionError: float division by zero
```

Vega/vega-lite output
items.body: Maybe?

items.title: Charts that cross zero should always have a tick at zero
Can't set temporal scale for line graph
items.body:
I have a list of tuples like:

`data = [(datetime.date(2001, 1, 1), 1000),(datetime.date(2001, 2, 1), 2000), etc...]`

and am instantiating a chart like so:

`chart = leather.Chart(title)`
`chart.set_x_scale(leather.Temporal(data[0][0], data[-1][0]))`
`chart.add_lines(data)`

But am getting the following error:

`unsupported operand type(s) for /: 'datetime.timedelta' and 'datetime.timedelta'`

Culprit appears to be on line 25 of temporal.py, in `project()`:

`pos = (value - self._min) / (self._max - self._min)`

items.title: Ensure bars/columns diverge from zero line if present
Pick a default them that's a little less Quartzy
items.body: Maybe something the color of LEATHER

items.title: Bars display in reverse (first tick should be at top)
Should have `add_x_scale` equivalent of `add_x_axis`
items.body:
`add_x_scale` > Linear
`add_x_timescale` > Temporal
`add_x_scale` > Everything else, including Ordinal?

items.title: Allow axis args to be passed into set_x_axis() rather than a constructed Axis object
items.body: It's too hard to simply tweak the ticks right now

items.title: Document callback function formats better in API docs
items.body: Just specify a function to reference

items.title: Support passing full table structures into Series
items.body:
X and y args specify column indices or accessories functions or key names (for DictReader format)

This will allow using non-coord columns in lambda funcs for styling and such

items.title: Issue a warning if data are outside of chart bounds
items.body: Trivial nice to have

items.title: Grid should have a background rect
items.body: And Chart.to_svg should maybe only add the background rect, rather than to_svg_group

items.title: Chart.to_svg should return a string if path is not specified
items.body: This will simplify testing too

items.title: Simple theming support
items.body: Almost everything is in `Axis`. Wouldn't be hard to encapsulate the rest of it and pass it in the chart constructor or something.

Automatic zero baseline for inferred bar/column scales
Wrap labels that include line breaks
items.body: Convert `\n` to `<tspan>`?

items.title: Document intentionally unsupported features
items.body:
- Right axis
- Top axis
- Multi-axis
- No axes
- Maps
- No ticks/grid
- 3D / multi-dimensional charts
- Annotations
